results.description:
Updated March 7th, 2016

Given the warmth that has descended upon NYC, I am making Tuesdays/Thursdays active again, but at 5pm.

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside and Booker T Washington as backups.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 5pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

BOOKER T. WASHINGTON DETAILS

This location is between 107th & 108th Streets just West of Columbus Avenue. It's on the backside of the high school. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. 

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
This Shakespeare play will be a  little different than usual as it will be An All Female Cast to celebrate body freedom and free expression.

• Note this play will have Nudity so if you are not into this kind of show, please Refrain yourself from RSVP.

ADAPTED AND CO-DIRECTED BY ALICE MOTTOLA AND PITR STRAIT

THU, MAY 19 AT 5:30PM

SUMMIT ROCK, CENTRAL PARK, NY, NY

FREE ADMISSION

http://www.thefreetempest.com/

About :

Celebrating Shakespeare’s final play on the 400th anniversary of the playwright’s death, writer/director Alice Mottola (Brightness) is collaborating with the OCTPFAS Theater Company to produce a dramatic re-imagining of The Tempest, to be performed by an all-female cast outdoors in Central Park in New York City on May 19 and May 20, 2016. Her co-director, Pitr Strait (Henry IV.1,The Skriker), is a veteran of Central Park Shakespeare, having directed Two Gentlemen of Verona and a previous production of The Tempest, and a long-time collaborator of Ms. Mottola's.

With Summit Rock (the highest natural elevation in Central Park) for a stage, this Tempest focuses on the contrast between the harsh restrictions of "civilization"—where political maneuvering costs thrones and lives—and the Edenic, magic-suffused tropical island on which the sorcerer Prospero and his daughter Miranda have lived in exile for twelve years. The contrast will be dramatized not only through performance and staging but also through inventive and integral use of costuming, with the harrowed, conspiring shipwreck victims initially forced to navigate the play’s island setting in constricting outfits suggestive of European aristocracy, in striking contrast to Prospero’s open and airy conjurer’s mantle, Miranda’s guileless, naked innocence, and the winged, painted form of the fairy Ariel.

“The Tempest is one of Shakespeare’s best-known and best-loved plays, but we want the audience to see it through fresh eyes, as ‘something rich and strange,’ the way an audience four hundred years ago would have,” said Ms. Mottola. A graduate of Barnard College with a degree in biology, Ms. Mottola's studies have also included acting, literature, and computer science. “To this end, we are very excited to make organic use of the natural resources we have: this beautiful natural setting in Central Park and the natural forms of our performers.”

The play’s selective use of nudity to dramatize The Tempest's central themes of alienation and reconciliation builds on a long tradition of free expression in theatrical productions held in outdoor settings. Past productions performed in Central Park, including Hair and Henry V, have featured full nudity in a similarly artistic, non-sexual context. Furthering that tradition, Mottola and Strait use nudity to communicate a broader message about body freedom, equality and open-mindedness, born of the production’s affiliation with one of the city’s long-standing organizations devoted to these topics, The Outdoor Co-Ed Topless Pulp Fiction Appreciation Society. The subject of profiles in theNew York Times, the Sunday Times of London, the Village Voice, Salon, the Huffington Post,Cosmopolitan, and elsewhere, OCTPFAS has worked for more than five years to educate the public about their legal rights and to change attitudes about non-sexual exposure of the human body.

"In nearly all of his plays, Shakespeare touched in one way or another on the collision between old and new, ordinary and radical," said Strait, a graduate of Columbia as well as The New School for Drama. "His final play is no exception. Because of that, The Tempest will always speak to an audience ready for new ideas. We hope our audience will leave our Tempest as transformed as our characters."

The production will feature a cast of eight actors, three dancers, and two musicians, with costume design by Delcey Fleming, body paint by Andy Golub, and assistant direction by Sarah Itzkoff.

Directions to Summit Rock from 81st Street and Central Park West (Summit Rock is also accessible from the 85th Street entrance).

1) Enter the park at 81st Street and Central Park West, on the uptown side of 81st Street.

2) Follow the road past the Diana Ross playground on your left, and keep bearing left. (When the road forks, stay on the leftmost path.)

3) Keep following the road as it curves left, up past a green sign that says "Summit Rock."

4) The path will wind upwards to a flight of stone steps. Climb them. You'll find a grassy lawn at the top with a stone stage in front of it and benches. Seating is also available on the ground between the benches and the stage. Feel free to bring a blanket, towel, or lawn chair!
results.name: Free play "The Tempest" by An All Female Cast

results.description:
Meeting Thursday, May 19, 2016 at Tekserve

1) Are you near me now? iBeacons and FileMaker Go 15


One of the new features of FileMaker Go 15 is support for Apple’s iBeacon standard. iBeacons are physical devices that use the Bluetooth Low Energy specification to broadcast positional signals on a continuous basis. iPads, iPhones, and iPod Touch devices running FileMaker Go 15 can read these signals and essentially poll a space where these iBeacons reside e.g. a retail store, warehouse, marketplace, trade show, etc. and get unique identifier and relative distance data that can then be used to query a database.

FileMaker Go 15’s native iBeacon functionality makes this type of application relatively easy to design and implement. J. Sciarra from Colibri Solutions will demonstrate this functionality and discuss various use cases, opportunities, and limitations of what this new FileMaker capability can provide.

2) FileMaker 15 round table

What is new in FileMaker 15? Let us explore together!

3) Bring your FileMaker questions and ask the audience. It is amazing how many problems a group of FileMaker developers can solve.

4) Picks and Tips of the Month: Short bits or bytes of interest to our NYFMP.org group members.

5:30 pm Meet & Greet

6:00 pm – 8:00pm Presentation
results.name: Are you near me now? iBeacons and FileMaker Go 15

results.description:
**There are 100 people signed up for the league who are there every night REGARDLESS of who is signed up from Meetup - so don't worry about how many people have RSVP'ed just here on Meetup.  We just leave up the Meetup for any new people (that's you!) who would want to come join us.  There are ALWAYS a ton of people.** 

Who: Exactly 1 buttload of good people
What: FREE Dodgeball!...then bar party with everyone!
Where: Manhattan, Upper East Side, St Joseph School, 420 E 87th St
Why: Fun n stuff
How: read below...

Oh hi there person reading this.  My name's Ari.  You should come play dodgeball with us.  That's a fun game.  Remember that from grade school?  Yeah, apparently when you're an adult you're still allowed to do that.  Who knew?  Oh, and now we get to go to a bar afterward instead of back to math class.  So there's that.  Adulthood has its perks.

See, here's some photos of shenanigans:

Doesn't that look like those people are having good times?  That could be you having good times!  You're a people!  And good times are the best kinds of times.

---

FAQ

SO WHO ARE YOU?
So the deal is that we're the group in NYC that gets together to play dodgeball every week...because we are overgrown children.  Sometimes old school rubber playground balls, sometimes little soft jello ones, sometimes some foam ones.  We're not here to F you.  That's why it's FREE for new folk.    But we're more a community than anything (but how legit does our website look?!) and just a good group of people running around with a childhood sport...and then, you know, a bar after if that's your thing.  

I WANT IN!  BUT WHAT IF I'M BAD/SCARED?
We don't just throw you to wolves - we'll introduce you around, explain everything, and no experience or athleticism necessary!  No one's gonna bully you or not want to play/hang out with you for being "bad" - no one cares about that...that's what a dick would do.  And we're not dicks.


WHAT IF I'M LATE?
It's just dodgeball, relax.  Come and go as you please.  The earlier you get there, the more you play of course, but no worries.

WHAT ABOUT MY STUFF? WHAT DO I WEAR?
There are bathrooms to change in if you need to.  Everyone leaves their stuff by the side of the court.  Plenty come straight from work.  Whatever you'd want to run around in is cool for clothes.  You wanna come in your work suit?  Rock on.

THIS IS AWESOME.  IS THERE A LEAGUE?!  I WANT MORE!

There is a full league that goes on too, if you're interested.  Same deal - good or bad all welcome!  More formal with teams and schedules and trophies and costume themes and karaoke and drink deals and all... More info here: www.sandlotsportsnyc.com/register , but any questions just lemme know!

Any questions, don't hesitate!  We'll get back to you! 

facebook.com/groups/NYCDodgeball
www.sandlotsportsnyc.com


A firm embrace,
Ari

<a href="http://www.sandlotsportsnyc.com"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: www.sandlotsportsnyc.com

results.description:
COME BREAK UP THE WORK WEEK AND JOIN US FOR A SUNSET MOUNTAIN BIKE RIDE AT MOHONK PRESERVE.

Please arrive by 6:00pm at the West Trapps Parking Lot to allow time to prep your bike and gear so that we may depart promptly by 6:15pm.

Starting from the West Trapps Lot we will Follow Undercliff Road to the Rhododendron Bridge.  We will cross over and take a right onto Oakwood Drive.  Next we take a sharp left onto Kleine Kill Road, then a left on Forest Drive, another left on Lake Shore Road and a right onto Long Woodland Drive which will take us to Humpty Dumpty Lane.

At Humpty Dumpty Lane we will stop at one of the Gazebos and take in the breathtaking views before our descent down Laurel Ledge Road and head back to West Trapps via Overcliff Road.

Please note: Our route may change slightly depending on the groups abilities, remaining daylight and enthusiasm levels. The addition of Duck Pond is an option that will cover more elevation if the group is up to it.

Distance: Approximately 12-13 miles

Estimated Bike Time: 2 hours

Difficulty: Ambitious Beginner / Intermediate - Gravel Carriage Roads with some Steep Hills

Current Weather Forecast: Partly Sunny with a high of 69 degrees

MANDATORY GEAR:

• Mountain Bike or Hybrid

• Bicycle Helmet

• Headlamp with spare batteries

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Clear eye Protection (safety glasses - for bugs, dirt, etc.)

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, Bugspray, etc.

• Bike Pump

• Tire Patch Kit and/or Spare Tube

PLEASE INSPECT YOUR BIKE PRIOR TO ARRIVAL TO INSURE THE FOLLOWING:

• Proper Tire Inflation

• Lubricated chain

• Properly Shifting gears

• Functional Brakes that don't rub rim or tire when released.

In Fairness to the group, anyone having trouble once we reach the Rhododendron Bridge will be asked to go back on the Overcliff Trail which is still a fun and scenic but shorter loop.

WHERE TO MEET?

West Trapps Parking Area - Mohonk Preserve

[masked],[masked]

RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set

(Specifically Trail Maps 105 & 106)

Also check this link for a .pdf of Mohonk's own Bicycle Routes map

(Please Note: More routes have been opened up to biking since the publication of this .pdf)

AFTERWARDS FEEL FREE TO JOIN US FOR SOME FOOD/DRINKS AT ONE OF THE MANY GREAT DINING VENUES IN NEW PALTZ!

All Bisexual, Non-monosxual, and all other Queer-identified and Bi-friendly people are invited to come join people from the greater NYC Area in a lively topic oriented discussion at  BiRequest's famously open, non-judgmental, safe space. If you can't make it to the meeting, feel free to join everyone afterward around "eight-fifteenish" for dinner.

about us: Thanks to the dedication and hard work of many good bisexual folk, BiRequest is a bisexual social discussion group serving the New York City metropolitan area since January 1994. We provide a safe space for bisexuals and bi-friendly people to gather and discuss issues of importance to us.

We're a co-ed group for adults from 18 to 80-plus who meet twice a month (starting in 2016, every 1st Monday and 3rd Thursday evening) at NYC's LGBT Center in the West Village. The meetings are moderated and focused on a discussion topic but not limited to that week's topic.

After the discussion group session, at 8 o'clock we go to dinner at a nearby, reasonably-priced restaurant for socializing and more informal discussion. We also have occasional social events such as movie nights, parties, and much more. Join us for a meeting or event and find the community you've been looking for!

People who can't make it to the meeting are invited to join our private online group BiRequest on Yahoo or on our Facebook Page BiRequest on Facebook.

results.description:
This is a[masked] level talk on Spark and Zepplin. It is not meant to be a deep-dive on any one of these technologies.

6:00 PM- 6:30 PM: Food, drinks, mingling 

6:30 PM - 6:45 PM: Ketur Shah and Artem Ervits Announcements, call for presenters, future events

6:45 PM: Alex Zeltov - Hands-On Intro to Big Data Analytics using Apache Spark and Apache Zeppelin

This workshop will provide an introduction to Big Data Analytics using Apache Spark and Apache Zeppelin.

There will be a short lecture that includes an introduction to Spark, the Spark components.

Spark is a unified framework for big data analytics. Spark provides one integrated API for use by developers, data scientists, and analysts to perform diverse tasks that would have previously required separate processing engines such as batch analytics, stream processing and statistical modeling. Spark supports a wide range of popular languages including Python, R, Scala, SQL, and Java. Spark can read from diverse data sources and scale to thousands of nodes.

The lecture will be followed by demo . There will be a short lecture on Hadoop and how Spark and Hadoop interact and compliment each other. You will learn how to move data into HDFS using Spark APIs, create Hive table, explore the data with Spark and SQL, transform the data and then issue some SQL queries. We will be using Scala and/or PySpark for labs.

Users have 2 options to follow along with the demo labs. You can use the:

* Hortonworks Sandbox on a VM No data center, no cloud service and no internet connection needed! Full control of the environment. http://hortonworks.com/products/hortonworks-sandbox/#install

* HDP 2.4 on Azure with Hortonworks Sandbox. Try Hortonworks Sandbox on Windows Azure. It’s free for the the first month, and there’s no need to download the VM!
http://hortonworks.com/blog/hortonworks-sandbox-with-hdp-2-3-is-now-available-on-microsoft-azure-gallery/

Alex Zeltov is a Solutions Engineer / Software Engineer / Programmer Analyst / Data Scientist with over 15 years of industry experience in Information Technology and most recently in Big Data and Predictive Analytics. Specializing in designing, developing and implementing complex software solutions. Experienced in all areas of the software development life cycle. Currently working as Solutions Engineer at Hortonworks, where he is responsible for creating high-value Hadoop solutions for customers. He created and delivered in-depth technical demonstrations and delivered custom big data workshops, POC’s for new and existing accounts. He holds an M.S. in Software Engineering degree from Penn State, as well as an undergraduate degree in Computer Science from Temple University. You can catch Alex on twitter @azeltov.

Following the Spark session, we have Ketur Shah from Microsoft present their data analytics solutions on Azure. 

Brief : Ketur Shah brings in over 2 decades of Capital Market and Banking experience and is a Solutions Architect at Microsoft in the Financial Services domain on the core Azure Platform, to architect and design solutions in Big data, Stream Analytics, Predictive Analytics, Data Visualization, Machine Learning, Blockchain and several other technologies on the Azure Platform.

Please provide your full name for Microsoft security.
results.name: Hands-On Intro to Big Data Analytics using Apache Spark and Apache Zeppelin

results.description:
Bring your positive mental attitudes and let's Move at a steady pace.

This is not a beginners hike as we're looking for a nice steady pace to enjoy elevating our heart rate and having fun.

You may want to bring a hat and a bug net for your head if it bothers you as this is the time of year for the divebombing little flying bugs.

[masked], [masked] are the exact GPS Coordinates for the trail head. The lower lot is technically right across the street from 64 Skyline Drive address.

5 - 7 ish miles, with about a 900 ft elevation gain

We will meet at the LOWER lot of skyline drive in Oakland at 6pm on Thursday evening. This will be approximately a 2 - 3 hour hike.

We will take the blue trail to Ramapo Lake and left on Lake Shore Drive Carriage Road around the lake to a brief meetup with the Cannonball trail but headed to orange. Once on orange we will cross over the pipeline and head to overlook view points and then follow the orange on a beautiful loop back to the pipeline. We'll then head up the pipeline to the top and make a right on the white trail that leads us to some nice views of a perhaps fading sunset and NYC skyline.


We will walk through the Van Slyke Castle. http://theoaklandjournal.com/oaklandnj/hike-into-history/"></a>" class="linkified">http://theoaklandjournal.com/oaklandnj/hike-into-history/; and descend down most likely we'll take the white back to lake shore road with a probable detour through an unmarked shortcut. Once on lake shore we can run, jog or walk back to the dam where we'll get some pics and hang out a bit before descending blue back to the parking lot.


This route may change from week to week depending on group so please have a map or gps.

http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/maps/NYNJTC_NJParkMaps-RamapoMtn_2015-85x11.pdf"></a>" class="linkified">http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/maps/NYNJTC_NJParkMaps-RamapoMtn_2015-85x11.pdf;

Bring headlamps, maps and water. Have fun!

FYI...Very good information about ticks available from the website link below. Helps to take away some of the mystery and scare tactics.

http://www.tickencounter.org

results.description:
The NYC Scrum User Group meets on the third Thursday of every month to talk about Scrum, to share experiences, to network, and to provide support for local Scrum practitioners. 

In May we are excited to welcome a special guest  - Petri Heiramo and offer you a workshop on user story splitting!

Workshop description:

Scrum requires that at the end of each iteration the Team will deliver a potentially shippable product increment. Thus, it would not be okay to just update the database this Sprint, and finish the UI and control layers in next Sprint. Nor would it be okay to code this Sprint and test in the next. But what if your requirements and features are too large to fit all the work in a Sprint?

Story splitting to the rescue. Let's explore together how we could do that for some challenging stories or bring in a sample from your own backlog! Pick one that your Team is having trouble making smaller - let's slice it in this workshop.


Short Bio:


Petri Heiramo is an experienced Agile trainer and coach. Certified by Scrum Alliance as a Certified Scrum Trainer in 2008, he has since trained a few thousand people as CSMs and CSPOs, in organisations ranging from small companies and startups, to multinational giants worldwide. 

Petri sees Agile as a holistic approach for business success. It's not just the teams; it's the culture and behavior of the whole organisation. All levels and aspects of the organisation should embrace the mindset, and then find the effective ways in which they can all work together to a shared goal. This is obviously easier said than done, particularly in large existing companies. Therefore it is important to remain practical in the adoption of Agile.

Agenda:


6:00 – 6:30 PM -Free Pizza & Networking

6:30 – 7:00 PM- Welcome and Update on our group initiatives:

Big Apple Scrum Day 2016 – Dana Pylayeva

Mentorship program – Jim Dermend /Kate Hana

7:00 PM – 8 PM - Thou Shalt Split Thine User Stories - 

a workshop with Petri Heiramo
results.name: Thou Shalt Split Thine User Stories

results.description:
Join us for our Digital Camera Workshop! There are a few spaces left so be quick!

Seminar: Digital Camera Thursday May 19th 6pm - 8pm

Each settings on your camera provides a world of potential for bettering your images. Whether you use a DSLR or a point and shoot, there are tons of tricks that you may be missing out on. We'll explore settings such as exposure compensation and various presets that can turn a regular image into a special one. Our knowledgeable instructors will guide you through all the main options that your camera has, and how and when to apply each of them based on the effect and scene that you are looking to portray.


Additionally, this class will thoroughly introduce to all other digital photography related topics that you will need to know when making your next camera purchase. These subjects include, megapixels, lenses, noise, white balance, ISO, SD cards and much more. Never miss that shot again! Join us and learn to maximize your camera's potential to match with your creative skills. Requirements: Digital camera (SLR or Point and shoot). No prior knowledge required.

Everyone is welcome!

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE VENUE CHANGE! 

Whole Whale created the first complete online course to maximize the Google AdWords Grant for nonprofits. The Grant is a use-it-or-lose-it, gone-by-midnight Cinderella situation, and we've studied how to maximize it for nonprofit impact. This presentation will provide you with training and specific strategies on how to leverage this grant to help the bottom line of your nonprofit.


Here's what you'll learn:

> Basic principles of Google Nonprofit Ad Grants and how to set it up

> Tips and tricks to make sure you’re maxing out the grant

> Advanced strategies on getting more bang for your buck

About our Speaker

Julie Leary | Digital Strategy Whaler, Whole Whale

After graduating from Princeton with a degree in Neuroscience, Julie ditched science for social cause and has worked at several nonprofits such as Association to Benefit Children in NYC, The SAMRO Foundation in Johannesburg, South Africa, and The Citi Performing Arts Center in Boston. Since joining Whole Whale, she has successfully managed more than a million dollars in digital advertising for nonprofits. She recently developed Whole Whale University, an online course that teaches nonprofits how to increase their impact by effectively utilizing the AdWords grant and social media. Julie loves finding smart ways to help nonprofits have huge online impact.

About Whole Whale:

Whole Whale is a digital agency that leverages data and technology to increase the impact of nonprofits. In the same way the Inuits used every part of the whale, WW leverages data and tech to increase organizational impact and reduce waste. By using data analysis, digital strategy, web development, and training, WW builds a Data Culture within every nonprofit they work with.

results.description:
Thuzio: Sports Stars & Celebrity Talent 
A Natural Fit for Inbound and Event Marketing

With some serious star power on the founders team, including Mark Gerson of Gerson Lehrman Group and Tiki Barber of the NY Giants, Thuzio is one of NYC’s notable start-up success stories. Recently securing another round of funding, this thriving company provides businesses and professionals access to celebrity talent through events, an online software platform and talent procurement services. Thuzio says its complementary products — Thuzio Executive Club and Thuzio 360 — offer clients the "perfect talent solution for all facets of the business community.”  And it is working. In less than two years, The Club has attracted almost 300 member businesses and produced over 150 events with sports stars and celebrities in five US cities. 


What is the secret behind Thuzio's marketing success? Mark Gerson, Co-Chairman/Founder, says their marketing is a continually unfolding story. The trick is to constantly innovate and try new things; then do more of what works. Thuzio started out with targeted outbound marketing to build brand awareness, acquire new influencers & customers and promote their upcoming events. "Executive Club events focus on helping people build their own personal networks by sharing unique, new and interesting experiences, so there is a natural tie-in for word-of-mouth referrals," says Gerson.

Event marketing is a natural fit for inbound marketing, both as a way to place content in front of appreciative audiences, but also utilizing the tactics of memorable experiences to build, promote, and leverage the value for clients and prospects. In this talk, Mark will explain how Thuzio uses content and the tactics of Inbound Marketing to:Find the right people for an eventDrive registrations with content Use shared social experiences to increase engagementLeverage video to share the passion and excitementGenerate awareness post-event


Date & Time: May 19, 2016, 6-8:30pm Event 

Location: WeWork* City Hall, New York City (For security reasons, no walk-ins accepted). Building entrance is located on Fulton Street. 

Agenda:

• 6-6:30 Networking

• 6:30-6:45 - Introductions

• 6:45-8:00 Speaker & Q&A

• 8:00-8:30 More networking and wrap-up

Speaker Information:
Mark Gerson is the co-founder and Chairman of the Gerson Lehrman Group and the co-founder and co-Chairman (with Tiki Barber) of Thuzio. 


He is also the co-founder and United Hatzalah and of United Rescue (the crowd-sourced system of volunteer first response, enabling victims of pre-hospital trauma to be treated in the moments that separate life from death) in Israel and the United States.  He is also the co-founder and Chairman of the African Mission Healthcare Foundation, which supports the work of Christian medical missionaries who provide much of the consistent clinical care in Africa. 


Mark Gerson's work on subjects from the biblical Jonah to the meaning of Frank Sinatra have been published in The Wall Street Journal, Commentary, USA Today and many other publications.  The author of books on intellectual history and education, he is a summa cum laude graduate of Williams College and is a graduate of Yale Law School.  Join us on May 10, 2016 at WeWork City Hall* for an in-depth look at Thuzio’s growing business and the marketing evolution that propelled its rapid growth.  

*Venue Sponsor - WeWork is the platform for creators.  We provide the workspace, community, and services you need to make a life, not just a living.  To learn more about the WeWork locations in New York City, click here to book a tour or send an email to [masked].
results.name: Influencers: Sports & Celebrity Talent; A Natural for Inbound & Event Marketing

results.description:
PARK WEST CAMERA CLUB's EXPANDING VISIONS 22!

Park West Camera Club’s Expanding Visions photography class is being offered this spring into summer.  It is open to all interested photographers.  This will be the 22nd consecutive year of Expanding Visions and this year's edition is a marriage of field trip classes with a class in photographic seeing. 

This nine week class (Thursday evenings, May 19th thru July 14th, 2016) will open your mind to new ways of looking at photographs, subject matter, equipment and techniques.  It will also allow you to explore parts of the City that you may not want to explore on your own.  The format of the class is simple: We start with an introductory session.  We will discuss equipment, techniques and the specifics of the course; a term project will be assigned.   For the second and third weeks we’ll go on field trips and work on assignments.  The fourth session will bring us back indoors where we’ll share our photographs, talk about our experiences and evaluate what and how well we learned the assignments.  The fifth and sixth weeks, field trips and assignments will be followed by another review at the seventh session. Then, the last trip and assignment  (eighth session) and the ninth and final review (including the term project presentations).  

This year will be a little different from other years.  All the field trips will be to the same destination—Times Square—the ”Crossroads of the World.”   This will allow us to familiarize ourselves with the destination and see how we can work it into the five different assignments.  There is a common theme running through the assignments: "Working the Subject."  Not too complicated, is it? Lots of fun and educational.  Most of all, it will expand your vision in the photos you take and allow you to grow as a photographer.  

The photo instructor for Expanding Visions 22, as has been for all the previous E.V.classes, is Chuck Pine.  The introductory session and the three review classes last for about two hours. The five field trips/assignments run for about one hour and a half.  The tuition for all 9 sessions is $75 or $15 per week (up to $75). Learn how your $75 can be applied to your future membership to the club.  The class is free to all PWCC members.   Cash or checks are accepted for all payments—sorry, credit cards are not accepted.  Please let us know if you will be coming.  Just drop us an e-mail of your intentions to <[masked]>

results.name: PARK WEST CAMERA CLUB's EXPANDING VISIONS 22, Begins May 19, 2016!

results.description:
Graybar Toastmasters is open to all who wish to improve their public speaking and leadership skills. In addition, this is a great way to network with a dynamic and diverse group of professionals.

Founded in 1954, we are one of the oldest Toastmasters clubs in New York City. We are a friendly club with members dedicated to helping each other become better speakers.

We meet from 6:15pm to 8:15pm on the 1st and 3rd Thursdays of each month in the same location. 

Our meetings are structured to allow everbody participate, practice and learn.

In our meetings the members of the club take different roles that allow them to practice and improve their public speaking and leadership skills by completing different projects.

The different roles include giving prepared presentations, chairing the meeting, improvising a short speech, telling a joke, giving feedback to speakers, evaluating the whole meeting, among others, all in a very friendly and supportive environment.

People who RSVP this meetup attend as guests. They introduce themselves at the beginning of the meeting and give feedback at the end, and some of them may participate in an improv exercise, this is an opportunity for you to check out the club coming to one or a couple of meetings, and decide if you want to join as an active member.


To learn more about Toastmasters International please visit http://www.toastmasters.org/

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: 28 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison in New York City. To enter, please press buzzer #2 outside the red door for the Gallery/Lounge on the 1st Floor. PLEASE attend the meeting only if you RSVP since the space available is limited.

results.description:
As an enthusiastic professional, have you ever wondered if there's a better way to expand your network and build your business than by going to drab breakfast meetings or mind-numbing gatherings in conference rooms?

Well, there is! Jam Bash Networking is putting a new spin on networking in Westchester and Fairfield Counties!

Jam Bash brings together jam band enthusiasts in a setting that combines the fun of a live show with the excitement of new business opportunities.

So don’t just work hard and play hard… work hard while playing hard!

-----------------------------------

Here’s how.

While there’s still time, sign up for the first-ever Westchester & Fairfield County Jam Bash Networking Event.

WHEN:   Thursday, May 19, 2016, 6:15 – 9:00 p.m.

WHERE:  Garcia’s at The Capitol Theater, Port Chester, NY

WHO:  Scott Metzger & WOLF!; Comedian Mike Finoia & over 200 jam band fans & professionals interested in networking. 

WHAT:  2.5 Hour Open Bar & Food; An hour of pre-show networking & cocktails; An hour-and-a-half of live jam band tunes, dancing and revelry.

When it is over, you walk away with more than just good vibes.  Each participant gets:

·  Solid connections with like-minded business people eager to expand their success.

·  A directory of contact information of all who attend.

·  Swag bag with cool stuff.

And don’t worry, there are rules!  By registering, each attendee will agree to our “NO NOODGE” policy.  This means No blast emails and No unwarranted solicitations.  Our goal here is high-quality, meaningful business interactions.

To sign up, go to Jambashnetworking.com, the Jam Bash Networking Facebook page or go directly to: brownpapertickets.com.  And hurry up, because space is limited!

results.description:
***NOTE*** This group is currently full. We are not accepting any more players at this time. Feel free to message me and I can reach out if a spot opens up in the future.


INTRODUCTION:Until just days ago, most members of our party were blissfully unaware of the Keys of Power and their creator, the Aramago. Even those that had any inkling of these topics thought the stories they’d heard to be mere legends. Then one of the Keys of Power was almost literally dropped in their lap. They were suddenly running for their lives guarding Melrick, the courier ferrying that item to a safe place.


Now, Melrick is dead and the party is cast adrift in an alien realm of existence. What’s worse, they’ve been separated from more than half of their number with seemingly no hope to reunite with them. So Theron, Clovis, and Drom cast about for ways to return to their home plane, reunite with their comrades, and most importantly, convey the precious cargo they carry to its rightful place.


However, all is not lost. Potential new allies have stepped forward. Already the elven ranger Thamior has shown his worth by warning the party of an impending ambush and nearly dying in helping to fight it off. And he’s introduced them to two more he knows can be trusted once the four of them reach the tiny village they hope will be a safe haven. They have just begun to relax for a much-needed warm meal when a gypsy strolls into the tavern and engages them directly with a desperate plea for help.


BACKGROUND:"The Keeper of the Keys" is a home-brewed, Dungeons and Dragons campaign. It is a shell that encompasses the numerous, separate adventures the players will enjoy during an epic quest to recover all the Keys of Power.


This game is one of two, biweekly games I am running in the Central Jersey D&D MeetUp group under the banner of “Adventures in Azocar”. It meets on the second and fourth Thursdays of each month. We may also have additional meetings if there’s a fifth Thursday in any given month but mostly, this will probably be kept open for make-up games.


I am looking for a group of players willing to commit to the schedule I propose; players whose attendance will not be an issue. These players also need to be ready to be involved in a long-running game. I know this because each time I've run "The Keeper of the Keys", it's encompassed almost the entirety of the PC's lifespan as adventurers.
results.name: The Keeper of the Keys - An Azocar Adventure

results.description:
Speaker: Hongbo Zhang, software developer at Bloomberg L.P.


The JavaScript platform is running everywhere with an extensive ecosystem but can rapidly become hard to maintain for large applications. OCaml is a very expressive and safe language which works well on such a use case. In this talk we will introduce a new OCaml backend for Javascript called BuckleScript which is uniquely designed for seamless integration with the JavaScript world. We will show how OCaml developers can leverage the Javascript tooling for both daily development as well as the release of their software to the popular Javascript platforms (Browser, Node.Js..)


Speaker Bio: Hongbo is a software engineer at Bloomberg. Before he joined Bloomberg, he received his master degree from the University of Pennsylvania and a bachelor degree from Tsinghua University. His master thesis is about meta-programming in OCaml(https://github.com/bobzhang/fan).

Thanks to Bloomberg for hosting this event and providing food and beverages.

results.description:
We are excited to have Dave Donars, Chief Research Officer and Brian Erickson, Chief Marketing Officer of Cardwell Beach, speak at our May SalesTech Meetup! Dave & Brian will speak about the guidelines that are applicable to the human psyche before technology and how to best leverage marketing technology to make selling easier! 

About Dave:

Dave is the Chief Research Officer for Cardwell Beach. He has worked in all essential forms of media and spent almost two decades learning how people define their personal media relationships. Dave has a deep background in both quantitative analytics as well as behavioral and ethnographic research. He works extensively with brands to understand the cognitive and emotional needs of their audience. A six sigma black belt with project management certification, Dave also focuses on consulting clients about how to streamline their workflow processes. His current focus is on helping brands deploy human automation and CRM systems. Prior to Cardwell Beach, Dave worked at large agencies, eventually forming the boutique digital consultancy Conveyer Media. His client experience includes American Express, One and Only, Volkswagen, Dow Jones, Samsung, BioGEN, Mikimoto, Dell, Novartis, AT&T, Nissan, Javelin Marketing Group, Rokkan, Omnicom, ConEd, Procter & Gamble, Wyeth, 3M, Mayo Clinic, Aetna, Army, National Academy of Art, Hyatt, BMW & Pepsi.

He lives in upper Manhattan with his two daughters.

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/convey


About Brian:

Brian has been the Chief Marketing Officer and a partner at Cardwell Beach since 2010. Brian leads the sales and marketing teams and is responsible for developing the Cardwell Beach brand; he also cultivates strategic relationships with business partners. He has an extensive background in B2B marketing, having worked on campaigns for Philips, Speedtest.net, Samsung, and Facility Solutions Group. Before Cardwell Beach Brian co-founded Kicknote, a tech startup aggregating real-time information on over 15,000 musicians, which was acquired in 2010. Brian recently ran his first NYC marathon, is an avid reader of psychology and is an electric guitar enthusiast.

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/brianerickson1

results.name: The Influence Effect: Adapting Sales and Marketing Techniques

Meeting nights will revolve between nights of writing together, nights of critique, and/or nights of discussion. Topics of discussion will include writing craft, the business of writing and the writers life. Introductions, individual goals and itinerary for future meetings will be discussed this first evening.

Whether you need a night away from the home front to focus on your writing among other writers, a venue where you can network with others to help navigate the self-publishing world, or someplace you can go to have your writing critiqued as you work your way through the rough spots, this group is designed to be a valuable resource for those looking to leave their DDJ (dreaded day job) to pursue a full time writing career.

Looking forward to seeing everyone there.

results.description:
Join us for an introductory dive into Ruby, a beginner-friendly language used on servers in backend web development (i.e., the stuff that goes on between entering a URL and getting a web page back). 


In this workshop, we will walk you through the basics of the Ruby language and how to use it to set up a basic web server. 

Key Takeaways:

• All the tools you need to get up, running and coding with Ruby 

• Ruby syntax for basic programming concepts like variables, loops, methods, strings, arrays and hashes 

• The basics of how the World Wide Web works under the hood 

• Setting up a simple web server and sending HTML pages to a browser 

• Using your server to interact with Twitter via its API 


Prerequisites and Preparation: 

• Please bring your own laptop (Mac, PC or Chromebook). 

•   Please download and install Sublime Text (Hint: the download button is on the home page). 

Light snacks will be provided. 

 
*This event is open to adult (18+) beginners and is an introduction to concepts covered more deeply in the immersive program.
results.name: Ruby For Beginners

venue.name: MediaMath

results.description:
Join us at MediaMath HQ in 4 WTC for a night of discussion about the underpinnings of the "cloud", running applications in hybrid environments, and the tricky aspects of running the internet in the "real world".

1) Building the Agnostic Data Center

Companies that provide enterprise software in industries that change rapidly face unique scaling challenges that require more independence, control, and responsiveness than either in-house or cloud architecture could provide on their own.  To provide their clients with enterprise-level service while maintaining a dynamic architecture that can support in-house and cloud environments, designers macro-manage their architecture from the beginning so that it can scale to enterprise-level. This talk will explain how MediaMath handled the Enterprise problem and how we designed an architecture that combined the flexibility of cloud architecture with the independence of owned hardware. We’ll share how we integrated dynamic virtual environments, dynamic storage, to cloud-based architecture use, and monitoring/analytics in an agnostic datacenter.

Presenting Company: MediaMath



2) Operating in a Hybrid World: Enabling networks and applications where you need them when you need them as it applies in the data center

Sabey Data Centers is an owner and operator of over 3 million square feet of data center facilities across the U.S. This talk will focus on building and operating Manhattan's only purpose-built data center at 375 Pearl Street for customers seeking a hybrid colocation environment.

Presenting Company: Sabey Data Centers



3) Making a bare-metal cloud: How Packet designed and built a fully dedicated, single tenant, bare metal cloud

Providing dedicated, bare-metal servers on demand with the same availability and flexibility of the virtualized public clouds presents a myriad of challenges. Network design, power management, out of band access, handling hardware failures, ensuring operating systems work with bare metal hardware without a virtualization layer, providing services like metadata that end-users have come to expect from the cloud were all challenges we faced while automating "layer 0" . Come hear how we designed and built the platform to provide a cloud experience without the downsides of co-tenancy and the convenience of a hypervisor in our toolkit.

Presenting Company: Packet

Presenters

Patrick Neville, Manager of Systems Operations, MediaMath

Patrick Neville is the Manager of System Operations in the Platform Operations tribe at MediaMath, where he specializes in composing infrastructure environments with hard-separated static and dynamic resources. 

Patrick has worn many hats in his career, from his start in a datacenter NOC, to DevOps/SysOps and site reliability engineering roles through his present role as a technical lead and mentor at MediaMath. He’s designed scalable architecture for almost every kind of application, amassing a wide range of skills along the way. Today he is a proud generalist who loves solving conventional problems with non-conventional, but intuitive, solutions. 

Dan Meltzer, Vice President Sales and Leasing - New York, Sabey Data Centers


Dan Meltzer has primary responsibility for sales and leasing at our Intergate.Manhattan data center located at 375 Pearl Street in New York City. From there, he leverages the entire Sabey Data Center national portfolio to meet his customers’ requirements beyond the New York market.

Dan is responsible for Sabey Data Centers’ relationships with telecom carriers both domestic and international and is also actively involved with Sabey’s cloud initiatives and IGX Networks, Sabey’s telecommunication services division.

Dan brings over thirty years of professional sales experience as well as key relationships in the telecommunications and data center industries having worked at MCI Telecommunications, PSINet, GlassHouse Technologies and, most recently, Optimum Lightpath. He is focused on several verticals for Sabey Data Centers including financial services, health care, new media, telecommunications and retail/wholesale colocation and hosting providers.

Dan lives in New York City and graduated from New York University with a Bachelor of Science degree.

Aaron Welch, SVP Product, Packet


Aaron comes from the digital agency background where his company Advomatic worked with high-profile clients in government, education and the non-profit sectors.  A veteran of the online political industry, he served as Internet Technology Director for Senator Chris Dodd’s 2008 Presidential campaign and was the Iowa-state web developer for Governor Howard Dean's Presidential campaign.

A server monkey at heart, Aaron created Advomatic’s boutique hosting division (Cadre), which was acquired by Packet in 2014. Originally from Seattle, and with a background in technical theatrical production, Aaron sits on the board of the Obie Award Winning Bushwick Starr Theatre.

In his spare time he scuba dives, eats fire and is a master of ceremonies for amateur talent shows.
results.name: The Cloud is just someone else's computer - an evening of infrastructure talk

results.description:
We're excited to present New York City's 2nd Annual Timmy Awards in an effort to recognize the best places for technology professionals to work. The "Timmys" are hosted by Tech in Motion, a national events organization for tech enthusiasts created by Jobspring Partners & Workbridge Associates. 

We are asking the NYC tech community to weigh in by nominating companies they believe deserve to win and then voting for the finalists! 

Organizations and individuals will be crowned the winners in each of the categories below on May 19th. The evening will begin with cocktails, hor d'oeuvres, music and more. 

• NYC's Best Tech Startup

• NYC's Best Technology Manager 

• NYC's Best Technology Work Culture (Over 500)

• NYC's Best Technology Work Culture (Under 500)

Visit Tech in Motion to learn more about The Timmy Awards!

Event MC: Dr. Rachel Schutt, Chief Data Scientist at News Corp

Dr. Rachel Schutt is the Chief Data Scientist at News Corp, which includes The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones, New York Post, Times of London, The Sun, The Australian; Harper Collins and Move. In this role, she is responsible for setting the global data strategy.  Rachel was named a World Economic Forum Young Global Leader in 2015, and is on the 2014 Crain's New York Business 40 under 40 list.

She is the co-author of the book "Doing Data Science" based on a class she created and taught at Columbia University, where she is an adjunct professor in the Department of Statistics. Rachel is a member of the Education Board for the Institute for Data Science at Columbia. Previously, Rachel was a statistician at Google Research and holds patents based on her work in the areas of social networks, large data sets, experimental design and machine learning.

She earned her PhD in Statistics from Columbia University, a Masters degree in mathematics from NYU, and a Masters degree in Engineering-Economic Systems and Operations Research from Stanford University. Her undergraduate degree is in Honors Mathematics from the University of Michigan. 


--

As always we would like to thank our sponsors Workbridge Associates and Jobspring Partners for sponsoring this event. 

Also big thanks to our Product and Community Partners:  Cater2.me, The Bosco, The New York Code + Design Academy and EventBrowse.com.

</a>

More about <a href="http://www.cater2.me/">Cater2.me:


Cater2.me was founded with the goal of connecting inspired kitchens with the masses. 

Inspired by San Francisco's thriving farmers' markets and the abundance of passionate local chefs, we decided it was time to revamp catering by opening up access to this amazing wealth of quality local food.

We've set out on a mission to connect companies with the local food scene, to give them a better, more wholesome sense of the small businesses around them. We enable these relationships through a mix of technology and committed customer service. No longer are you only able to read about the hottest chefs and food startups while at work – we're bringing them into your offices and homes.

Cater2.me stands for curated quality and variety, trusted service and dead-simple ordering. At Cater2.me, Your Catering is Our Business!

More about  The New York Code + Design Academy:

The New York Code + Design Academy offers full-time and part-time classes in web and mobile app development for both beginners and experienced developers. Gain valuable instruction from working developers, build projects, and join our supportive coding community. Visit NYCDA.com for more information on our programs & upcoming events.

----

Is there something you are trying to accomplish in the NYC tech community? Whether it be product marketing, user acquisition, employment branding, or thought leadership, Tech in Motion: NYC can help!  We currently have 2016 sponsorship opportunities available that will align with the goals you’re trying to achieve with your new app, company, or upcoming event. For more information follow this link or send us a meetup message!

results.description:
This is a free group for anyone who enjoys playing board games and would like to make new friends while doing so. No previous knowledge of board games is necessary. We're happy to help newcomers along with how to play, as well as how to plan strategies to win the games.  

Our event is every Thursday night at Dave & Buster's in Westbury Long Island from 6:30pm to 10:30pm.  You can leave prior to 10:30pm if you want, also please note that Dave & Buster's closes at Midnight for those who want to stay later. 

Most people arrive at 6:30pm.  We use the first 30 minutes to talk, order food/drinks, and pick out games while we wait for any people that are a little late.  Promptly at 7pm we split into groups and play our games that typically take 2 hours to play.  So, if you arrive after 7pm there is a good chance that you will not be able to get into a game and can watch us play if you'd like.  At the end of the night we play a couple of additional shorter games that you can get into.

This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's (We are located 1 room over from the pool tables).  There is no cover charge to enter Dave & Buster's and plenty of parking is available. Also, there is no fee to join this meetup group. All that management at Dave & Buster's asks is that each person purchase $5 off their menu (it can be 1 appetizer, or 1 dessert, or a few sodas, basically whatever you choose).  

Plenty of board games will be present at this event, but feel free to bring some of your favorites. Some of the games that we play are Kingsburg, Stone Age, Lords of Waterdeep, Istanbul, Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Love Letter Batman, Splendor, Pirate's Cove, Five Tribes, Castles of Burgundy, and more.  

Here is a list of the board games I own on the BGG website: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/MarkNY8?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Here is a list of Co-Host Kenny's games on BGG: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/kenk1982?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Looking forward to meeting you. 

Mark

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
